title: In the Drops: Reserve’s genius tubeless valves, Pas Normal Studios gravel kit, a neat backpack from Chrome and crazy golf
content:

In the Drops: Reserve’s genius tubeless valves, Pas Normal Studios gravel kit, a neat backpack from Chrome and crazy golf

I don’t know about you, but the clocks going forward and the seemingly endless evenings British Summer Time brings inevitably puts me a positive and productive frame of mind. It’s had a similar effect on my colleagues too, for this week has been a vintage one for content on cyclist.co.uk.

The stream of new product launches, which continues to flow with abundance, was the source of plenty of our published articles.

NoPinz launched a gravel skinsuit, Cannondale added a fancy Lab71 option to its Topstone gravel bike range, Specialized lopped the bottom half of its Sirrus commuter bike’s seat tube off to give it a ‘Compliance Junction’, Canyon revealed it’s dabbling in 3D printed titanium, Kask revised its Utopia helmet and DT Swiss made updates to its CRC wheel line too.

We’re supporting the tech news with some big ol’ reviews too: Cyclist web editor Matthew Loveridge tested Specialized’s Diverge STR and mag deputy editor James Spender’s review of the Cervélo S5 will be published later on today.

Given we’re peak Spring Classics season and the Tour of Flanders is this weekend, our pro coverage was pretty good as well. We ran the latest edition of our Pro Log series, took a peek behind the scenes at Flanders, looked at the riders that should be in the mix for this year’s race, got Johan Museeuw’s perspective on it too and published Classic Climbs features on the Koppenberg, Oude Kwaremont and Paterberg to boot. What a bunch of busy bees.

Nonetheless, the week wouldn’t be complete without an edition of our In the Drops weekly round-up, so here is some of the best kit to arrive with us over the few days.

Pas Normal Studios Escapism gravel kit

Pas Normal Studios caters unusually well for gravel riding in its comprehensive Escapism collection. As well as there being plenty to choose from, the garments are all smartly constructed using fabrics and features that lend themselves to off-road adventures.

The Technical T-shirt is case in point. Pas Normal Studios has taken what is generally a very simple design and added some nice extra touches that help set it apart.

The fabric is said to be abrasion-resistant so it should resist trailside things like brambles pretty well, and there’s a DWR-treated panel of even tougher fabric across the lower back to fend off wheel spray.

The T-shirt also includes zips either side of the torso, running up from the bottom hem to roughly halfway. Pas Normal Studios says these will improve ventilation, but also provide easy access to the back pockets of the Escapism bib shorts…

…which are another example of something simple done smartly. The body fabric is four-way stretch nylon, so despite feeling sturdy and dense should be flexible and comfortable.

A pair of cargo pockets offer plenty of capacity to carry easy-to-reach essentials on your thighs, and a double pocket on the lower back increases the bibshorts’ carrying capacity yet further still, which of course the zippered T-shirt should allow unencumbered access to.

Reserve Fillmore valves

These little valves might not look like much, but if they work as advertised, they represent one of the biggest technological leaps forward for some time in making in making tubeless easier to set up and live with.

Traditional Presta valves have been around for over a hundred years now and have served us well in that time. However, they don’t play well with tubeless – more often than not, you need to remove the valve core to allow enough airflow through them in order to seat the tyre, and they’re liable to clogging with sealant too, sooner or later.

In its Fillmore design, Reserve aims to sidestep the Presta valve’s potential flaws. It does away with the cramped valve core that sits inside the valve stem, instead using a thin rod that extends down through the valve stem.

The valve itself is formed right at the stem’s base: pushing down on the rod shifts the poppet on the end of it away from the base of the valve stem, opening a port through which air and sealant can enter the tyre cavity more readily.

Reserve is claiming up to three times more airflow for its Fillmore design and say the design is impervious to clogging too.

Even the valve cap is natty. Cinched tight, it protects the top of the valve as you’d expect, but loosening it off a touch allows it to depress on to the valve, for letting off tyre pressure cleanly if required.

  • Buy the Reserve Fillmore valves from jungleproducts.com (£34.99)

Chrome Ruckas backpack

Chrome products are loved for their durability, and being built to last has the beneficial side effect of reducing waste. Chrome’s new Ruckas backpack can claim double eco-points though, for not only has it been built to be typically robust it has been made from recycled materials too.

The Ruckas’ 23-litre capacity is divided up fairly simply, but there are enough pockets and holders to store a variety of items in securely.

Despite the bag cutting an overall slim profile, the main compartment is roomy, with a document sleeve against the back wall of the bag, off of which hangs a number of smaller pockets for organisation.

On the outside, there’s a large stash pocket on the front, a bottle holder on the side and a padded laptop sleeve cleverly snuck in between the bag’s main compartment and the user’s back. As bags go, the Ruckas looks to have everything you need and nothing you don’t.

  • Buy the Chrome Ruckas backpack from chromeindustries.com (£115)

What we’re into this week: Crazy golf

I don’t mind a round of golf but even if you’re of the opinion that the sport is a great way to ruin a good walk, it’s impossible to dislike crazy golf.

It has plenty of the elements that make the proper game so popular. It’s tricky and unpredictable and can rely on a fair degree of luck, despite your performance still being ultimately governed by skill and determination.

That said, if you play badly, who cares? You’ve just hit the ball into the mouth of a giant duck – the number of strokes it took you to do so can easily become irrelevant if you want it to be.

Crazy golf also removes many of proper golf’s perceived disadvantages too. It doesn’t take five hours to finish the game, you don’t return home physically and mentally drained and sunburnt, the necessary ability level to play is much lower and you don’t even have to wear chinos.

What’s more, it’s family friendly – kids and partners are likely to enjoy it just as much as you are, perhaps even more so when your son has just sunk a hole in one and you’re three shots deep and still nowhere even close.

I’m aware that I’m writing for an audience of cyclists, so stick with me: a lot of parallels can be drawn between the two sports. Cycling, just like real golf, can be pretty exclusive, time-consuming and serious, but as there isn’t really a cycling equivalent of crazy golf (BMX is probably too dangerous for most, myself included), I think it’s a pretty valid option if you need to lighten the mood once in a while.
